headline: Electrical Engineering & Computer Science Student at UC Berkeley
about: 🌟 Passionate about Advancing Society through Technology 🚀Hello LinkedIn community! 👋 Excited to connect with you all. I'm Leo Nagel, a student at UC Berkeley, diving deep into the realms of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering. My journey at UC Berkeley has sparked a profound interest in how technology, particularly in the realm of generative algorithms, can shape a brighter future for us all.Exploring the intersection of computer science and electrical engineering, I'm deeply intrigued by the potential of generative algorithms to revolutionize various aspects of our lives. From fostering creativity to tackling complex societal issues, the applications of this technology are vast and promising. Outside the academic realm, I've been actively engaged in projects exploring the practical implications of these concepts, fueling my passion for leveraging technology to drive positive change.Keen to connect with fellow enthusiasts and professionals who share a vision for harnessing technology to enhance society. Let's collaborate and explore the endless possibilities together!

people_also_viewed.summary:
Six Degrees of Robotics
        
              
          🌐 Groundbreaking Compression Standard for Haptics Published! 🌐

The Technical University of Munich (TUM) has led an eight-year effort culminating in the publication of the first standard for the compression and transmission of the sense of touch, named "Haptic Codecs for the Tactile Internet" (HCTI). This pioneering standard lays the groundwork for advancements in tele-surgery, tele-driving, and immersive gaming experiences.

Haptic codecs, much like JPEG for images and MP3 for audio, enable the efficient transmission of tactile information over the Internet. The new IEEE standard 1918.1.1 encodes and decodes data to allow users to experience remote tactile interactions, such as feeling the grip of a robot arm or the texture of materials like paper or metal.

Prof. Eckehard Steinbach, leading the research at TUM, highlighted the challenge of transmitting haptic feedback, which requires bidirectional data flow and ultra-low latency to maintain realistic interactions. The new standard reduces the clock rate from 4,000 to 100 times per second, aligning closely with human perception thresholds.

The applications of HCTI are vast:

⚕️ Telesurgery: Enables surgeons to perform operations remotely with precision, even across long distances.

🚚 Teledriving: Facilitates remote control of vehicles, enhancing safety and flexibility in autonomous driving.

💉 Emergency Medical Services: Allows remote ultrasound diagnostics by doctors while en route to hospitals.

🎦 Entertainment: Enhances realism in gaming and films by transmitting physical sensations.

💻 E-commerce: Provides tactile feedback for online shoppers, enhancing the shopping experience.

This new standard is expected to spur innovation and new applications, much like JPEG and MP3 did for their respective fields.

For more details, visit TUM's official website -https://lnkd.in/eDfvSz_x

To access the standard, visit IEEE here - https://lnkd.in/eenTQAaH

QCFD
        
              
          📢 New Insights in Quantum Gate Design with Reinforcement Learning

Our recent collaborative research involving the University of California, Berkeley, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, the Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems, and Forschungszentrum Jülich has focused on leveraging reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize control pulses for transmon qubit entangling gates.

In this study, we utilized a continuous control RL algorithm to design high-fidelity, entangling two-qubit gates for superconducting qubits, such as cross-resonance and CNOT gates. Our approach does not rely on prior information about the physical system, which allows the RL agent to explore a broader range of pulse sequences. The results showed that the RL-optimized pulses not only surpassed standard cross-resonance gates in fidelity but also reduced gate duration, while maintaining robustness against stochastic noise.

These findings highlight the potential of RL-based optimization methods to enhance quantum gate design, contributing to the development of more efficient and scalable quantum computing systems.

📚 For more information, please read the full paper here: https://lnkd.in/eMc97S8i
 
Authors: Ho Nam Nguyen, Felix Motzoi, Mekena Metcalf, K. Birgitta Whaley, Marin Bukov, Markus Schmitt.

#QuantumComputing #ReinforcementLearning #SuperconductingQubits #QuantumControl #QCFD #ResearchUpdate

EPFL Electrical And Micro Engineering
        
              
          🎉 Congratulations to Ming-Lo Wu from the AQUA – Advanced Quantum Architecture Lab - on the successful defense of his PhD thesis “Single-Photon Avalanche Diode Image Sensors for Harsh Radiation Environments” under the supervision of Prof. Edoardo Charbon.

🔎 The thesis investigates both the theoretical limits and the practical performance of SPAD image sensors across diverse applications, including high dynamic range imaging, fluorescence lifetime imaging, light-in-flight imaging, and particle detection. Additionally, the study examines the impact of harsh environmental conditions such as radiation, temperature, and lighting on the performance of SPAD image sensors.

ETH AI Center
        
              
          🌟 Exciting Updates from ETH AI Center at ICLR! 🌟
Last week, our dedicated PhD & Postdoctoral fellows showcased their innovative research across various fields at the ICLR conference. Here’s a glimpse into the work they presented:

🔍 Alizée Pace tackled the challenge of uncertainty in offline learning. Her method introduces a new way to measure uncertainty, enhancing the reliability of conclusions in real-world applications. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/d4Wnm8_D

🔍 Manish Prajapat developed a novel learning approach for scenarios where rewards diminish over time. This method is particularly effective for route planning and environmental monitoring. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dgS_HbvR

🔍 Emanuele Palumbo introduced a model that learns from diverse data types, such as images and text, without extensive labeled examples. It efficiently organizes output into groups, even without predefined categories. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dvsFTaNh

🔍 Riccardo De Santi simplified how computers learn from past experiences with a new method that uses intuitive diagrams instead of complex formulas, proving effective in data-scarce situations. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dthk8EX8

🔍 Javier Rando explored the risks of training large language models that could be manipulated to produce harmful outputs. His work includes a test to help prevent such issues. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dHpMFqfn

🔍 Dr. Theodora Kontogianni and Dr. Francis Engelmann introduced AGILE3D, a model that enhances 3D object outlining by allowing multi-object segmentation, reducing the need for manual corrections, and increasing efficiency. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/etcJcQ3V

🔍 Dr. Francis Engelmann also improved visual-language models for 3D scene segmentation with OpenNeRF, which integrates VLM features into 3D rendering, achieving superior performance. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dnawDNQ6

🔍 Chenhao Li created a method that enhances machine learning from motion data by identifying patterns to better predict and understand movements, aiding adaptation to new environments. Read the full paper: https://lnkd.in/dA8WevYM

We are proud of our fellows’ contributions to advancing AI research and their commitment to solving complex global challenges. Join us in celebrating their achievements!
#AIResearch #ICLR #MachineLearning #Innovation #ETHZurich

Jaishnoor K.

https://lnkd.in/gvYDwgFc

The juxtaposition of these two articles, released within a short time of each other (5 days!), is a testament to the risks and rewards of Gen AI. It also highlights the increasing importance of cybersecurity and the new challenges we face.

Universum Labs
        
              
          🦗 Relatively quiet day on the quantum front — but there is quantum excitement to be had in Berkeley Lab’s process for identifying and fabricating quantum materials. Plus, if there were QIS standards for secondary schooling, these would be it.

⚆ Researchers at Berkeley Lab have combined rapid computational predictions with precise fabrication techniques to accelerate the discovery of quantum materials; the results are shared in a publicly available database called the Quantum Defect Genome

⚆ IBM has become a partner in the Superconducting Quantum Materials and Systems Center at Fermilab, focusing on advancing superconducting quantum computing technology through tackling challenges in quantum computing, communication, large-scale deployment, and the workforce

⚆ Quandela and Welinq have teamed up to combine their expertise in quantum processors and interconnect technology to create custom quantum links for photonic quantum computers

⚆ attocube systems Inc is providing essential tools for the quantum technology supply chain to improve energy efficiency for scalable quantum computing applications

⚆ The case for integrating quantum informatics into secondary school curricula is made by positioning it within traditional computer science education, aligning it with the Great Principles of Computing, and establishing standards for expected student outcomes

⚆ Don't miss a single qubit -- follow Cierra Choucair & subscribe to the free newsletter for your daily quantum computing news & research insights.

The Quantum Insider
        
              
          Scientists from Pasqal and the University of Exeter developed a differentiable quantum generative modeling protocol to efficiently solve stochastic differential equations and generate multidimensional probability distributions.

ETH Zürich researchers demonstrated a provable quadratic speedup in kernel-based quantum learners by incorporating Grover's algorithm into a quantum support vector machine.

Diraq's team developed a global control scheme for semiconductor spin qubits to overcome issues related to frequency crowding to move towards fault-tolerant quantum computing on a silicon-CMOS platform.

And much more. Read every qubit 👉https://lnkd.in/gM2rn3bK

Terra Quantum AG
        
              
          🌌 Where Quantum Physics Meets the Fabric of Spacetime

We are proud to share an achievement by our Terra Quantum AG team, published in the journal Entropy MDPI. Led by Florian Neukart, Reuben Brasher, and Eike Marx, this research introduces the Quantum Memory Matrix (#QMM) hypothesis—a revolutionary framework that addresses one of the most profound questions in physics:

What happens to information when it falls into a black hole?

The #QMM proposes that spacetime itself acts as a dynamic quantum memory, preserving and encoding information through “quantum imprints.” This ensures that information is never truly lost, even in the extreme conditions of black hole evaporation. By reconciling Quantum Mechanics and General Relativity, the #QMM offers new perspectives on the interplay between quantum information and spacetime dynamics.

But why does this matter for quantum technology?

🔗 Information Encoding and Retrieval
The #QMM provides a foundational mechanism for encoding and preserving quantum information—the core of quantum computing. Its insights into how information behaves in extreme environments like black holes could inspire breakthroughs in error correction, data storage, and distributed quantum systems.

⚛️ Quantum Dynamics in Spacetime
By revealing how quantum states interact with spacetime, the #QMM opens new paths for innovations in quantum communication, cryptography, and sensing technologies.

💡 Advancing Quantum Innovation
At Terra Quantum AG, we are committed to connecting theoretical breakthroughs with practical applications. The #QMM’s insights could help redefine how we process, secure, and utilize quantum information across a range of industries.

This work not only pushes the boundaries of physics but also demonstrates Terra Quantum AG’s dedication to bridging the gap between theory and technology. It’s a step toward understanding how quantum principles and spacetime dynamics intertwine—laying the groundwork for the next generation of quantum innovation.

📚 Read the full paper here: https://lnkd.in/eF8XHPgM and below 👇

Congratulations to Florian Neukart, Eike Marx, Reuben Brasher, and the entire team for their remarkable contribution to science and technology!

#QuantumIsNow #QuantumComputing #QuantumPhysics #QuantumGravity #Innovation #QuantumMemoryMatrix Markus Pflitsch

Berkeley Industrial Engineering & Operations Research
        
              
          Congratulations to Berkeley IEOR PhD student Haoting Zhang, fellow PhD student Jinghai He, recent alum Jingxu Xu (PhD ’24), and Professor Zeyu Zheng for winning the Best Theoretical Paper Award at the 2024 Winter Simulation Conference.

The INFORMS Winter Simulation Conference is a leading global forum that highlights the transformative role of simulation in system design, innovation, and operations. The Best Theoretical Paper Award is given annually to one outstanding paper among all accepted theory-focused contributions, recognizing exceptional contributions to advancing simulation methodologies. This recognition underscores the impact of Zhang, He, and Xu’s research in the evolving fields of AI and simulation.

You can read more about the award here: https://bit.ly/40sxsot

#research #machinelearning #ucberkeley #AI

Science Featured
        
              
          Exploring the Invisible Forces of Angular-Momentum Waves in Physics - https://scft.link/uW3w5

Professor Jing-Ling Chen, Xing-Yan Fan, and Xiang-Ru Xie from Nankai University have discovered angular-momentum waves, potentially revolutionizing our understanding of particle physics. 

Their study was published in the journal Results in Physics. These waves, derived from the Yang-Mills equations, suggest new insights into the fundamental forces of nature and potential technological advancements.

#angularmomentum #particlephysics #YangMills #physicsresearch #sciencefeatured #sciencenews

Research & Analysis Institute
        
              
          🚀 Revolutionizing Material Discovery with AI-Driven Electron Structure Calculations

Researchers at Yale University have developed a groundbreaking AI-based method that dramatically accelerates the computation of electronic structures in materials—a crucial step in understanding their properties.

💡 Key Highlights:

Innovative Approach: Leveraging a variational autoencoder (VAE), the method creates a compact, unsupervised representation of the electron wave function.

Efficiency Boost: Reduces computation time from a million CPU hours to just about an hour!

Applications: This breakthrough is particularly impactful for studying 2D materials, enabling rapid exploration of their excited state properties and behaviors.

Impact: Opens new possibilities for discovering materials with enhanced light interaction, conductivity, and more, making previously inaccessible calculations feasible.


🔬 Why It Matters:
By slashing computational costs and time, this innovation democratizes access to complex simulations, empowering researchers worldwide to accelerate advancements in material science.

📖 Dive deeper into the details here: Faster Electron Structure Calculations Make Material Discovery Easier

Let’s connect to discuss how AI is reshaping the future of computational science! 🌟

#AI #MaterialsScience #QuantumMechanics #ComputationalChemistry #Innovation #Research #Breakthrough
